title: Biden Lifts Covid-19 Caps on Employees in Federal Workplaces
sub_head: Under new guidance, U.S. government agencies must develop a return-to-work plan by July 19
body:
WASHINGTON—Federal agencies will no longer be required to limit the number of employees in their workplaces but will maintain a telework policy established during the Covid-19 pandemic, the Biden administration said Thursday.
The guidance issued by three federal agencies lifts a 25% limit on capacity within the offices of federal agencies, reversing a policy issued in January, and sets up planning for the return of workers to federal offices, such as courthouses or U.S. Embassies.
Federal agencies will need to complete their return-to-work planning by July 19, the administration said. The plans should address how and when employees and contractors can return to their in-person duties, according to the guidance.
A federal task force earlier this week said U.S. employees and contractors may voluntarily share information about their vaccination status, but it isn’t a requirement that workers be vaccinated. When a federal worker or contractor voluntarily discloses being unvaccinated or declines to provide information about vaccination status, agencies should implement mitigation measures, such as masking and physical distancing.
Late last month the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission issued updated guidance stating that federal laws don’t prevent a U.S. employer from requiring workers to be vaccinated.
